top_comment.text:
I am a heterosexual Christian male, and a combat veteran of the regular 
army fought in Afghanistan 06-07 Korengal. 

I have gay friends, and I did ask God and pray about homosexuality because 
it is considered controversial.  My answer was that 1: It is none of my 
business 2: Homosexuality is no excuse to not come to Christ and be 
embraced with the love only God can give.

Ignorance and intolerance just leads to more of the same on each side. 
 Donahue fights against something, but it his own personal war, because if 
it is God's will that homosexuality be fought against, he will do so.  It 
is a Christian's duty to spread the love of word of god, not exclude and 
condemn others because we feel they don't deserve it.  On the flip side, 
responding with Leviticus and challenging someone's beliefs with responses 
that are just meant to be damaging is wrong.  I want safety and assurance 
for all people, homosexual or otherwise.

If anyone reads this comment, please remember that we are all sinners. 
 Everything must be brought before God, no one else.  It will not be a man 
that judges us for our lives, and so no ones judgement can be absolute on 
earth.  The one and only sin that can never be forgiven is knowing God, 
knowing love, and turning away.﻿

comments.text:
+Lab Rat Sorry for late response, I am not always signed in with my account 
but my wifes.  I would contend there is no contradictions in the Bible, and 
on that I am not here to argue with you.  Everyone is entitled to their own 
beliefs and the liberty to share those beliefs.  I agree with you, even now 
I watch atheist videos about Christianity and lately I feel a calling about 
the hypocrisy in our Churches today, about those who twist the message and 
use it to fill their own selfish agendas.  These need to be called out, the 
hateful messages need to be shown for what they are, and the perversion of 
the word of God must end.

What I am saddened to see is people considered leaders of the Church being 
the impression of Christians as a whole.  There are people who will spout 
Bible verses at others, thinking that this is how you spread the word of 
God.  I have been guilty of this a few times in my life, and it has never 
worked out well.  I am excited and zealous of my faith in God, I know for a 
fact he works in my life, and I am happy with what God provides for me. 

That happiness didn't come from being judgmental, spitting hellfire and 
brimstone at the non believers.  It came from LISTENING to EVERYONE, 
praying to God to let him use me to help anyone I can, and through God and 
the teachings of Christ I better those around me by the way I live my life. 
 It will be God that opens his arms to any who come to him through Christ, 
not me or anyone else on this Earth.  Man is the reason for hypocrisy and 
hateful debates of this world, not God.  The only way to change this world 
and uproot the evil is to change ourselves, and so doing change all around 
us like a ripple in a pond.

I hope you know that I pass no judgement on you, TYT or The Catholic 
League.  I only pray for those stuck in the vicious cycle of hate and 
offense that so easily takes us all at times.  God has shown me grace, and 
I have seen it as pure love and a beautiful gospel to share with all I can.
comments.author: DENNIS HALE

comments.text:
When Jesus had finished saying these things, he left Galilee and went into 
the region of Judea to the other side of the Jordan. Large crowds followed 
him, and he healed them there.

Some Pharisees came to him to test him. They asked, “Is it lawful for a man 
to divorce his wife for any and every reason?”

“Haven’t you read,” he replied, “that at the beginning the Creator ‘made 
them male and female,’ and said, ‘For this reason a man will leave his 
father and mother and be united to his wife, and the two will become one 
flesh’? So they are no longer two, but one flesh. Therefore what God has 
joined together, let no one separate.”

“Why then,” they asked, “did Moses command that a man give his wife a 
certificate of divorce and send her away?”

Jesus replied, “Moses permitted you to divorce your wives because your 
hearts were hard. But it was not this way from the beginning. I tell you 
that anyone who divorces his wife, except for sexual immorality, and 
marries another woman commits adultery.”

The disciples said to him, “If this is the situation between a husband and 
wife, it is better not to marry.”

Jesus replied, “Not everyone can accept this word, but only those to whom 
it has been given. For there are eunuchs who were born that way, and there 
are eunuchs who have been made eunuchs by others—and there are those who 
choose to live like eunuchs for the sake of the kingdom of heaven. The one 
who can accept this should accept it.”

comments.author: Henry Gould

comments.text:
Easy. The Torah is a polytheistic text, and if you learn a bit about 
Mesopotamian and Babylonian history you can prove it. Noah's ark is a story 
that was plagiarized from the myths of the Babylonians (read the Eridu 
Genesis and epic of Atrahasis) and Jews weren't even 100% monotheist at the 
time the Torah was written. In fact, certain Hebrew words that still exist 
today were originally the names of Sumerian gods. Take for example the word 
Shamash. In the context of modern Hebrew it means the candle of the 
hanukiah that you use to light the other candles, correct? Shamash was 
originally the name of the Sumerian god of the sun about 5000 years ago. 
That's around 2000 years before the ancient nations of Judah and Israel 
even existed. Once again, during the Babylonian exile the ancient Judeans 
(Jews) came into direct contact with Babylonian mythology. The Babylonians 
utilized a very large amount of the Sumerian religion in their own myths 
and legends. The epic of Atrahasis I mentioned above, for example, is taken 
from the older Sumerian epic of Gilgamesh. In the case of certain gods such 
as Shamash (and I am using Shamash as an example specifically),  the 
Babylonians often times wouldn't even bother to change the names of their 
gods from the Sumerian name. If Even modern Hebrew still contains clear 
traces of polytheism, as does the Torah itself with stories like that of 
moses smashing the ten commandments after seeing his people praying to the 
golden bull idol, then it should be painfully obvious that other sections 
of the Torah (like leviticus which condemns homosexuality or the part that 
condones slavery which I think was in deuteronomy but I'm not quite sure) 
should not be taken literally. In fact you could argue that if there truly 
is one god (assuming you aren't an atheist like me) and the Torah is 
littered with polytheist influences, classifying the Torah as a holy book 
that is literally true is effectively polytheism which, obviously, would 
contradict the concept of monotheism modern Judaism is founded upon. You 
could thus go so far as to suggest that someone truly Jewish shouldn't 
consider the Torah as a law book at all but rather as a hybrid text 
containing both mythology and fragments of the history of the Jewish 
people. If the book is no longer observed as a law book, there's no longer 
any reason to take leviticus seriously. If you're interested in the various 
other links between Sumerian, Babylonian and Jewish religion, you should do 
a bit of further research. There are in fact other connections between them 
that I have not listed here.
comments.author: kisamehoshigaki09

top_comment.author: Julia Baum

comments.text:
Julia, I grew up in a Catholic School from primary school through high 
school. Over those years, like you, I was taught many things that later I 
discovered were not necessarily the case. For instance, I was taught that 
the Roman Catholic Church is the only true church. All the Protestant 
churches were basically going to hell. 

With regards to homosexuality, it in itself is not sinful. One cannot 
control how one's body responds to another sexually. One's sexual response 
is part of the autonomic nervous system and is involuntary. However, it is 
the selfish engagement in sexual activity that is sinful, whether it is 
heterosexual or homosexual. The key word is selfish. I believe that 
selfishness is original sin because all other sins stem from it. Maybe 
bring this up with your teachers in class. It would be a good discussion 
topic.

As to the Old Testament, it came down through the ages primarily in oral 
traditions. Some were written in scrolls but mostly by word of mouth. Have 
you ever played that group game where you tell something to the person next 
you and that person 'repeats' it to the next person, etc until it comes 
back to you? What comes back you rarely is what it started out to be. That 
is what one can visualize when reading the Old Testament and some of the 
New Testament. Jesus told us that He came to fulfil the OT. Let's just take 
our cue from Him and His teachings and example. We can't go wrong.

We have to decide for ourselves what is right and go with the conscience 
that God gave us.

God bless.

comments.text:
For some males and females, it is not natural for them to be attracted to 
the opposite sex. It has to do with how their brain formed in their 
mother's womb. For a man to be heterosexual, his brain needed to be infused 
with testosterone. That hormone is necessary to form the structures in his 
brain that control such characteristics as thought processes, mannerisms 
and sexual attraction to the female. This all takes place in the first 20 
weeks after conception. By the 20th week, these characteristics are already 
hard-wired in the brain.

However, if testosterone is released late or sporadically, the brain will 
develop strongly female by default. The probability of the resulting male 
child growing up to be homosexual or bisexual is very high. Did you know 
that only 10% of males are 100% heterosexual? With the exception of 10-20% 
who have no sexual attraction, the rest of the male population has at least 
some homosexual tendencies. our sexuality is a result of inutero physical 
development, both heterosexuality and homosexuality can be considered 
phenomena.

comments.text:
There is a second story in the bible called a Levite and his Concubine and 
in that story a man, his male servant and his concubine (stay at home 
whore) visit a town and a guy lets them stay at his house. The men of the 
village demand that he send the strangers out so they may rape them and so 
the Levite sends his concubine out she is gang raped and crawls back 
presumably dieing on the steps of the house. The Levite then takes her 
home, chops up her body and sends it out to the 12 tribes of Israel. At no 
point does god nuke the city nor does he say the Levite was a bad guy for 
throwing a woman out there to be raped to death or desecrating her body. If 
anything Sodom and Gomorrah was anti angel rape not anti gay because 
obviously rape is fine in the bible and god doesn't nuke everyone who wants 
to have sex with men. Remember this is the same book that allows you to 
rape a woman if you kill her family in war times.

comments.text:
^I live in Canada. I dont trust the Conservatives or the Liberals. For the 
first time ever I voted NDP...begrudgingly... Whenever I look at USA 
politics I think... "Man...it sucks that they have only two parties". Then 
I look at Canada where we have 4+, and they all suck. Politics is a joke. 
Its not about working together, to get shit done, to try and better a 
country. Its just a sweet job for a bunch of people, some fame, and petty 
squabbles like children, who rarely ever get anything significant done. 
Liberal, Conservative, same shit. Nothing gets done with any meaning 
anymore.
Whoever is in power proposess idea X.
Opposition party immediately goes as far opposite to X as possible.
In Canada we have 4+ parties.
Leader says idea X.
3 opposition parties all explain why X wont work. Try to force elections, 
rinse recycle repeat. NOTHING GETS DONE.

comments.text:
+6chhelipilot I believe we as individuals are our greatest obstacles. We

same thing done to us.
comments.author: Dark Knight Goes into Hiding

comments.text:
+Michael Simmons

Is that what you believe, or is that what you know?

In either case, it's a completely immoral world view to hold.

So, regardless of the good that someone is doing now, if they get knocked 
down by a car today, that's justice for something they did in a previous 
incarnation. Really?

You're an immoral thug if you believe that. That's a doctrine that allows 
people to walk by beggars in the street and think to themselves: 'Well, 
it's your own fault'.
comments.author: 6chhelipilot

comments.text:
+6chhelipilot the only way for a baby to be treated or someone who can't 
defend themselves, is based upon their previous karmic debt upon 
incarnation on the Earth, that is divine justice and reciprocal action.
comments.author: Dark Knight Goes into Hiding

comments.text:
+6chhelipilot Egoist, Atheist, Idolaters, Hedonists, etc. Would have you 
believe this is all their is too life, but it's simply not true.

Death is only an escape to those who have managed to break all worldly 
fretters and ascend, for everyone else. Death is a cycle that goes on 
immeasurable, nothing is evil or wrong with death knowing we all will do it 
at some point in time.

But the transition based on karmic-debt and inheritance can be troublesome, 
you should never overlook or simply think it's coincidence, or chance, it's 
not.

Karma literally means "what you do."

Yes the golden rule, so it would be ignorant to look at one side of karma 
and say, "treat others the way you want to be treated," and not see the 
other side that says "because the way you treat others is the way you will 
be treated"
comments.author: Dark Knight Goes into Hiding

comments.text:
+Michael Simmons

"If their is no God, if their is no afterlife, if their is no laws of 
reciprocal action. Nothing is wrong with rape, murder, genocide, 
selfishness, deceit, slander, infidelity etc."

I'm so glad that you believe in a God and an afterlife.

The laws of reciprocation have no supernatural cause. Animals, other than 
humans, demonstrate that to be a fact.

You also have a responsibility to the other 7 billion people that reside on 
this planet, to do them no harm.

The Golden and Silver rules should suffice as a way to live together 
without having to resort to unprovable supernatural claims about 
after-lifes that make the life that we do know we have seem like some sort 
of carpet to wipe our feet on before going on to the next one. 

 All versions and forms of the proverbial Golden Rule have one aspect in 
common: they all demand that people treat others in a manner in which they 
themselves would like to be treated, regardless of their 
supernatural/religious beliefs.

"Never impose on others what you would not choose for yourself." etc.

 So, what is it that you would actually choose to do to others if there 
were no Gods or some sort of afterlife?
comments.author: 6chhelipilot

understood as synonyms.
